content: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
meta: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.
Number and Operations—Fractions

content: Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.
meta: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.
Number and Operations—Fractions

content: Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; understand a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b.
meta: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.
Number and Operations—Fractions

content: Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.
meta: Reason with shapes and their attributes.
Geometry

content: Understand that shapes in different categories (e.g., rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may share attributes (e.g., having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger category (e.g., quadrilaterals). Recognize rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals, and draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.
meta: Reason with shapes and their attributes.
Geometry

content: Solve real world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.
meta: Geometric measurement: recognize perimeter as an attribute of plane figures and distinguish between linear and area measures.
Measurement and Data

content: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.
Measurement and Data

content: Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm, square m, square in, square ft, and improvised units).
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.
Measurement and Data

content: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.
Measurement and Data

content: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Show the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in appropriate units— whole numbers, halves, or quarters.
meta: Represent and interpret data.
Measurement and Data

content: Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several categories. Solve one- and two-step "how many more" and "how many less" problems using information presented in scaled bar graphs.
meta: Represent and interpret data.
Measurement and Data

content: Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using standard units of grams (g), kilograms (kg), and liters (l). Add, subtract, multiply, or divide to solve one-step word problems involving masses or volumes that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as a beaker with a measurement scale) to represent the problem.
meta: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation of intervals of time, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.
Measurement and Data

content: Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing the problem on a number line diagram.
meta: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation of intervals of time, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.
Measurement and Data

content: Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10—90 (e.g., 9 × 80, 5 × 60) using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Fluently add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Use place value understanding to round whole numbers to the nearest 10 or 100.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of operations.
meta: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.
Operations and Algebraic Thinking

content: Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
meta: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.
Operations and Algebraic Thinking

content: Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 × 5 = 40, one knows 40 ÷ 5 = 8) or properties of operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.
meta: Multiply and divide within 100.
Operations and Algebraic Thinking

content: Understand division as an unknown-factor problem.
meta: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.
Operations and Algebraic Thinking

content: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.
meta: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.
Operations and Algebraic Thinking

content: Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three whole numbers.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.
Operations and Algebraic Thinking

content: Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.
Operations and Algebraic Thinking

content: Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 56 ÷ 8 as the number of objects in each share when 56 objects are partitioned equally into 8 shares, or as a number of shares when 56 objects are partitioned into equal shares of 8 objects each.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.
Operations and Algebraic Thinking

content: Interpret products of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 5 × 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.
Operations and Algebraic Thinking

content: Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same denominator by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
meta: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.
Number and Operations—Fractions

content: Express whole numbers as fractions, and recognize fractions that are equivalent to whole numbers.
meta: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.
Number and Operations—Fractions

content: Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions, e.g., 1/2 = 2/4, 4/6 = 2/3). Explain why the fractions are equivalent, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
meta: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.
Number and Operations—Fractions

content: Understand two fractions as equivalent (equal) if they are the same size, or the same point on a number line.
meta: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.
Number and Operations—Fractions

content: Represent a fraction a/b on a number line diagram by marking off a lengths 1/b from 0. Recognize that the resulting interval has size a/b and that its endpoint locates the number a/b on the number line.
meta: Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.
Number and Operations—Fractions

content: Represent a fraction 1/b on a number line diagram by defining the interval from 0 to 1 as the whole and partitioning it into b equal parts. Recognize that each part has size 1/b and that the endpoint of the part based at 0 locates the number 1/b on the number line.
meta: Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.
Number and Operations—Fractions

content: Recognize area as additive. Find areas of rectilinear figures by decomposing them into non-overlapping rectangles and adding the areas of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real world problems.
meta: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.
Measurement and Data

content: Use tiling to show in a concrete case that the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths a and b + c is the sum of a × b and a × c. Use area models to represent the distributive property in mathematical reasoning.
meta: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.
Measurement and Data

content: Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.
meta: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.
Measurement and Data

content: Find the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths by tiling it, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths.
meta: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.
Measurement and Data

content: A plane figure which can be covered without gaps or overlaps by n unit squares is said to have an area of n square units.
meta: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.
Measurement and Data

content: A square with side length 1 unit, called "a unit square," is said to have "one square unit" of area, and can be used to measure area.
meta: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.
Measurement and Data
